g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Adapter (=Wrapper) Convert the interface of a class to anothe...
g.text: Adapter (=Wrapper)Convert the interface of a class to another interface that the client expects or requires.

g.title: Folded Corner.20
g.desc: The Adapter design pattern compliments the Open Closed princi...

g.text: The Adapter design pattern compliments the Open Closed principle by retaining existing implementation and interfaces. This ensures stability within the code base. All aspects are compared against an implementation where Adaptee or Target are changed to unite their interfaces. Stability, because the risk of breaking production and test is mitigated. The Adaptee or Target interface could be ‘deeply’ intertwined with the rest of the system. Changing them would cause other clients (test/production code) to break, resulting in an increase in maintainability effort and bug introduction. An Adapter overcomes this change and provides us the conversion between interfaces (bi- and/or unidirectional). This compliments the OCP, because we don’t modify existing code, instead we introduce a new class with the responsibility to make the interfaces between sub-parts of our system compatible. On top of that, in case we need a different Adapter (e.g. we want to have a new Adaptee), our client remains untouched due to the applicability of DIP between client and adapter.

g.title: Rectangle.47
g.desc: (1)Connect two incompatible, existing interfaces, without cha...
g.text: (1)Connect two incompatible, existing interfaces, without changing them

g.title: Rectangle.52
g.desc: (2)Subclasses lack common functionality, but the base class m...
g.text: (2)Subclasses lack common functionality, but the base class may not be extended

g.title: Folded Corner.54
g.desc: The Adapter pattern might be used to extend the interface of ...

g.text: The Adapter pattern might be used to extend the interface of an existing class. A use case might be that several subclasses require an extension of their interface, but the base class may not change. A possible solution is to subclass each concrete class and add the new functionality. This would however result in duplicate code across concrete classes. The Adapter pattern prescribes sharing this new functionality via the use of an Adapter class. This Adapter class exposes the new, extended interface to the clients and allows injection of the concrete classes. The Adapter delegates the calls to the concrete classes (when possible) and implements the new functionality.

g.title: Folded Corner.57
g.desc: The Adapter pattern both entails the negative and positive si...

g.text: The Adapter pattern both entails the negative and positive side of the Open Closed Principle. The Adapter between Adaptee and Target interface introduces an additional form of indirection. This has negative impact on the navigability and debuggability of the code. It might be ‘simpler’ to just modify the Adaptee to fit the required Target interface, instead of introducing an extra class (=Adapter).

g.title: Folded Corner.64
g.desc: The Adapter pattern compliments the Single Responsibility Pri...

g.text: The Adapter pattern compliments the Single Responsibility Principle by extracting interface ‘translation’ logic from client code. This has positive impact on the readability, stability and reusability of the code. All aspects are compared against an implementation where interface ‘translation’ logic is situated within the client code. Readability, because client code is not obscured with translation logic, that would otherwise distract from its essence. Stability, because the chance of breaking code unrelated to the Adapter logic is mitigated. In contrast, when the Adapter logic resides inside the client and change is required in the Adapter logic, then the chance of breaking unrelated code is increased. Reusability, because extracting adapter logic from client code increases the reusability of this logic across other clients. As stated in point 2 of the When? section, multiple subclasses can reuse the same Adapter logic (=Pluggable Adapters).

g.title: Folded Corner.73
g.desc: The Adapter pattern can be used to connect classes with incom...

g.text: The Adapter pattern can be used to connect classes with incompatible interfaces. A common scenario is that our system is dependent on an existing interface and the implementation behind that interface requires change. This is relatively easy in case a new implementation can be introduced and adapted to the interface. The problem however arises when an already existing implementation (=Adaptee), with a complete different interface, needs to be connected to the existing interface (=Target). Changing the existing implementation or interface might be undesirable or not possible (e.g. an external library). In this case a ‘translator’ between the two interfaces is required. The Adapter pattern prescribes that an Adapter wraps-a or inherits-from an Adaptee and facilitates translation to the Target interface. Using this approach, the existing implementation or interface do not require change.
